words.ENTRY:
gamenouncountablea form of play or a sport with rules;
a time when you play it: Let's have a game of chess.a game of football/baseball/tennisOur next game is against the Boston Eagles.

<H>gap</H><audio>gap.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><CF>a gap (in/between something)</CF> <D>an empty space in something or between two things:</D> <X>The sheep got out through a gap in the fence.</X><dot><X>He has a gap between his two front teeth.</X>

getverb(present participle getting; past got; past participle, except in sense 1 gotten) 1.have/has got to have something: I've got a headache.2.to become: It's getting dark.She got angry.3.to receive or obtain something: I got a letter from my sister.He went shopping and got a suit.She got a job in a travel agency.Nina gets $10 an hour for working in her family's business.

giftnouncountablesomething that you give to a person;
a present: wedding giftsTheir teacher was presented with a gift of flowers and candy.They often give away a free gift with the magazine.

<H>girl</H><audio>girl.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><NR>1.</NR><D>a young woman:</D> <X>He was 18 before he became interested in girls.</X><dot><X>The girl at the checkout was very helpful.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>a female child:</D> <X>the little girl who lives next door</X><dot><X>There are more boys than girls in the class.</X><NR>3.</NR><D>a daughter:</D> <X>They have two boys and a girl.</X>

<H>girlfriend</H><audio>girlfriend.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><NR>1.</NR><D>a girl or woman with whom somebody has a romantic and/or sexual relationship</D> <NR>2.</NR><D>a girl or woman's female friend</D>

goverb(present participle going; third person singular goes; past went; past participle gone)1.to move or travel from one place to another: We're going downtown."Is Anita here?" "No, she went home."How fast does this car go?2.to travel to a place to take part in an activity or do something: Are you going to Dave's party?Do you want to go swimming this afternoon?They went on vacation.3.to visit or attend a place regularly: Does Jacob go to school yet?4.to leave a place: I have to go now. It's almost 4 o'clock.5.to happen in a particular way: Hi, Mark. How's it going? (= How are you?)My work's going pretty well.

golfnoununcountablea game that is played outdoors on a large area of grass (a golf course) and in which you use a stick (a golf club) to hit a small hard ball (a golf ball) into a series of holes (usually 18): to play a round of golf

goodadjective(better; best) 1.of a high quality or standard: a good book/movie/concertThe hotel was really good."Why don't you apply for the job?" "I don't think my English is good enough."2.good at something; good with somebody/
something able to do something or deal with somebody/something well; successful: Jane's good at chemistry.He's very good with children.3.pleasant or enjoyable: It's good to be home again.good news/weatherHave a good time!4.morally right or well behaved: She was a very good person. She spent her whole life trying to help other people.5.good (to somebody) kind; helpful: They were good to me when I was sick.6.good (for somebody/
something) having a positive effect on your health: Green vegetables are very good for you.7.suitable or favorable: This beach is very good for surfing.I think Paul would be a good person for the job. good morning/afternoon/evening/night (used for greeting somebody) well1adverb(better; best) 1.in a good or satisfactory way: You speak English very well.I hope your work is going well.Did they treat you well?2.thoroughly, completely, or carefully: Shake the bottle well before opening.well2interjection1.(used when you begin the next part of a story or when you are thinking about what to say next): Well, the next thing that happened was ...Well now, let me see...2.(used for expressing doubt, hesitation, etc.): "Do you like it?" "Well, I'm not really sure."Her new boyfriend seems, well, a little strange.
<H>good-looking</H><audio>good-looking.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>(usually used about a person) attractive</D> <X>Paul is really good-looking. He looks like Brad Pitt.</X>

graduateverb graduate (from something) to finish your studies at a school, college, university, etc. and receive an official piece of paper (a diploma) that shows that you have finished:
I graduated from Florida State University with a degree in biology in 2005.
grandmanouncountable(informal) grandmother; the mother of one of your parents

greatadjective1.(informal) good; wonderful: We had a great time in Florida.It's great to see you again.They were great friends.2.particularly important; of unusually high quality: one of the greatest scientists of the 20th centurya great moment in history3.(formal) large in amount, degree, size, etc.; a lot of: We had great difficulty in solving the problem.The party was a great success.It gives me great pleasure to introduce tonight's guest.
<H>green</H><audio>green.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>of the color of grass or leaves:</D> <X>dark/light/pale green</X><dot><X>olive green</X>
guynouncountable(informal) a man or a boy: He's a nice guy.
gymnouncountable(informal) gymnasium; a large room that contains equipment, e.g. bars, ropes, weights, treadmills, etc. for doing physical exercises
